skill.name: ghe-thread-manager
skill.description:
Use this skill when the user expresses ANY intent related to issue/thread management:

- Switching issues: "let's work on X", "switch to #Y", "go to the auth issue"
- Checking status: "what are we working on?", "current issue?", "status?"
- Background work: "what's in background?", "any features ready?", "check progress"
- Starting development: "implement X", "add feature", "fix bug Y", "build a..."
- Joining reviews: "let me see the review", "check that feature", "join #X"
- Pausing/resuming: "pause this", "come back later", "resume #X"
- Stopping transcription: "stop tracking", "don't record this", "private mode"
- Resuming last session: "what were we working on?", "resume last issue", "continue where we left off"
- Any natural expression of wanting to change focus or check work status

This skill interprets natural language - users should NOT memorize commands.
For the full GHE workflow protocol, see skill: github-elements-tracking

security_audit.summary: Static scanner flagged 109 patterns as potential security issues. After manual review, all findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The skill is documentation that teaches Claude to manage GitHub issue transcription by calling legitimate GHE Python scripts with hardcoded paths and no user input injection vectors. No cryptographic operations, no command injection risks, and no prompt injection attempts detected.

high_findings.title: False Positive: Cryptographic Algorithm Detection
high_findings.description: Scanner incorrectly identified timestamp formatting patterns (YYYYMMDDHHMMSSTimezone at line 54) and YAML frontmatter as weak cryptographic algorithms. No encryption, hashing, or cryptographic operations exist in this file.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Timestamp formatting patterns and YAML frontmatter fields do not constitute cryptographic algorithms. Scanner misidentified date format strings.

high_findings.title: False Positive: Hidden File Access Detection
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged ~/.claude directory reference as hidden file access. This is legitimate plugin configuration directory documentation for the Claude plugin system.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: ~/.claude is a standard Claude plugin configuration directory, not a hidden file access vulnerability.

medium_findings.title: False Positive: External Command Execution Detection
medium_findings.description: Scanner flagged bash script examples as external command execution. These are legitimate GHE Python script calls with hardcoded paths and no user input injection vectors. Documentation only, not executable code.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: All script calls use hardcoded paths (${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT}/scripts/) with no user input injection. Legitimate GitHub integration documentation.

medium_findings.title: False Positive: Temp Directory Access Detection
medium_findings.description: Scanner flagged /tmp directory usage as a security concern. This is legitimate temporary file usage for workflow state management (ghe_previous_issue file).
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: /tmp usage for issue tracking state is standard practice with no security implications.

low_findings.title: False Positive: Standard Device File Access
low_findings.description: Scanner flagged standard shell redirections (2>/dev/null) and GitHub API calls as device file access. These are standard shell scripting practices for error handling and external API integration.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Standard shell redirection and API calls are legitimate scripting practices, not device file vulnerabilities.

content.value_statement: Managing GitHub issue threads manually is error-prone and lacks continuity across sessions. The ghe-thread-manager skill enables Claude to track, switch, and resume issue-based conversations with automatic transcription to GitHub for persistent memory across sessions.
actual_capabilities: Detect natural language intent for issue switching and status checking
Manage GitHub issue transcription state (ON/OFF) with user notifications
Switch between issues while maintaining transcription context
Create and track background development threads
Resume previous sessions by finding last active issue
Handle edge cases like session resume and fallback issue discovery
limitations: Requires GHE (GitHub-Elements) plugin installation to function
Cannot operate without GitHub CLI (gh) authentication
Limited to GitHub issue-based workflows only
Depends on GHE Python scripts (auto_transcribe.py, create_feature_thread.py)

use_cases.title: Multi-Issue Development Projects
use_cases.description: Switch between different GitHub issues for features, bugs, and reviews without losing context. Claude maintains separate conversation threads for each issue with proper transcription.
use_cases.target_user: Developers managing complex projects with multiple concurrent issues

use_cases.title: Session Continuity and Resumption
use_cases.description: Resume previous work sessions by automatically finding the last active issue. Claude remembers where you left off even across different Claude sessions.
use_cases.target_user: Developers who work on long-running projects across multiple sessions

use_cases.title: Background Development with Maintained Context
use_cases.description: Start background feature development while keeping the main conversation on a parent issue. Background threads don't interfere with main issue context.
use_cases.target_user: Developers using async development workflows with multiple agents

prompt_templates.title: Basic Issue Switching
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to work on issue #42 about the login bug. Switch our conversation to that issue.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to switch to a specific GitHub issue

prompt_templates.title: Status Check
prompt_templates.prompt: What issue are we currently working on? What was the last thing we discussed?
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to know current transcription state and previous context

prompt_templates.title: Background Thread Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement a dark mode feature for the settings page. Start the background thread but keep our conversation private.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to start feature development without changing main issue context

prompt_templates.title: Session Resume
prompt_templates.prompt: Resume where we left off. What were we working on last time?
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to continue a previous session by finding the last active issue

output_examples.input: Switch to issue #42 about the login bug
output: Transcription is now ACTIVE. Everything we discuss will be posted to Issue #42 (Fix login bug) on GitHub.
Say 'stop tracking' or 'go private' at any time to disable transcription.

output_examples.input: What were we working on last time?
output: Your last conversation was on Issue #42: Fix login bug.
Would you like to resume? (This will turn transcription ON)
Transcription stopped. Our conversation is now private - nothing will be posted to GitHub.

best_practices: Always inform users before turning transcription ON - their words become public on GitHub
Use natural language patterns instead of memorizing specific commands
Maintain separate transcription context when creating background threads
Save previous issue state before switching to enable 'go back' functionality
anti_patterns: Silently changing transcription state without user notification
Assuming the user knows whether transcription is active
Mixing background thread context with main issue context
Forgetting to check current state before performing issue operations

faq.question: How does transcription work in GHE?
faq.answer: Transcription means posting conversation exchanges to a GitHub issue. When transcription is OFF, the conversation is private. When ON, every exchange between you and Claude is posted to the selected issue, creating a permanent record.

faq.question: Can I work on multiple issues at once?
faq.answer: Yes. You can have one main transcription context (main issue) while creating background threads for other work. Background threads don't affect the main transcription state.

faq.question: What happens when I say 'implement feature'?
faq.answer: Claude creates a background feature thread using the GHE agent workflow (Athena writes requirements, Hephaestus implements, etc.). This does NOT change your current issue context - main conversation stays as it was.

faq.question: How do I find what I was working on previously?
faq.answer: The auto_transcribe.py script automatically tracks the last active issue in .claude/last_active_issue.json. Say 'what were we working on?' or 'resume last issue' to find and optionally resume it.

faq.question: What if the last issue file doesn't exist?
faq.answer: The skill includes a fallback that searches GitHub for your avatar in recent issue comments to find your last active conversation.

faq.question: How do I switch back to a previous issue?
faq.answer: Say 'go back' or 'return to previous issue'. The skill saves the previous issue number before each switch, allowing easy navigation between issues.
